content: Min Chinese language **Pu–Xian Min** ([Hinghwa Romanized](/wiki/Hinghwa_Romanized): *Pó-sing-gṳ̂*; [traditional Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 莆仙話; [simplified Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 莆仙话; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Púxiānhuà*), also known as **Putian–Xianyou Min**, **Puxian Min**, **Pu–Xian Chinese**, **Xinghua**, **Henghua**, **Hinghua** or **Hinghwa** (*Hing-hua̍-gṳ̂*; [traditional Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 興化語; [simplified Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 兴化语; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Xīnghuàyǔ*), is a [Chinese language](/wiki/Chinese_language) that forms a branch of [Min Chinese](/wiki/Min_Chinese). Pu-Xian is a transitional variety of [Coastal Min](/wiki/Coastal_Min) which shares characteristics with both [Eastern Min](/wiki/Eastern_Min) and [Southern Min](/wiki/Southern_Min), although it is closer to the latter. The native language of [Putian people](/wiki/Putian_people), Pu-Xian is spoken mostly in [Fujian](/wiki/Fujian) province, particularly in [Putian](/wiki/Putian) city and [Xianyou County](/wiki/Xianyou_County) (after which it is named), parts of [Fuzhou](/wiki/Fuzhou), and parts of [Quanzhou](/wiki/Quanzhou). It is also widely used as the mother tongue in [Wuqiu Township](/wiki/Wuqiu,_Kinmen), [Kinmen County](/wiki/Kinmen), [Fujian Province, Republic of China](/wiki/Fujian_Province,_Republic_of_China) (Taiwan). More than 2,000 people in Shacheng, [Fuding](/wiki/Fuding) in northern Fujian also speak Pu-Xian. There are minor differences between the dialects of Putian and Xianyou. Overseas populations of Pu-Xian speakers exist in [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia), [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia) and [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). Speakers of Pu-Xian are also known as [Henghua](/wiki/Henghua), Hinghua, or Xinghua. ## History Before the year 979 AD, the Pu-Xian region was part of Quanzhou county and hence people there spoke a form of [Southern Min](/wiki/Southern_Min). In 979 AD, during the [Song dynasty](/wiki/Song_dynasty), the region was administratively separated from Quanzhou and the Chinese spoken there developed separately from the rest of Southern Min. Due to its proximity with Fuzhou, it absorbed some elements of [Eastern Min](/wiki/Eastern_Min), such as morphophonemic alternations in initial consonants, but its basic linguistic characteristics, i.e. grammar and most of its lexicon, are based on [Southern Min](/wiki/Southern_Min). It also shares denasalization of historical nasal consonants and vocalic nasalization with [Southern Min](/wiki/Southern_Min) varieties. Pu–Xian Min has been shown to be 62% cognate with [Quanzhou dialect](/wiki/Quanzhou_dialect) (Southern Min) and only 39% cognate with the [Fuzhou dialect](/wiki/Fuzhou_dialect) (Eastern Min). ## Characteristics ### Differences with Southern Min dialects Pu-Xian differs from most Southern Min varieties in several ways: - The vowel 'a' is replaced by /ɒ/ (o̤) in most cases, e.g. 腳 *ko̤* "leg". - The vowel 'ư' /ɯ/ is replaced by /y/ ('ṳ'), e.g. 魚 *hṳ* "fish". - In Putian 'ng' has changed to /uŋ/ except after zero initial and h- (notation: ng), e.g. 湯 *tung* "soup". - The vowel /e/ is often replaced by /ɒ/ o̤, e.g. 馬 *bo̤* "horse". - Where Quanzhou has 'ĩ' and Zhangzhou has 'ẽ', the corresponding Putian vowel is 'ã', e.g. 病 *baⁿ* "sick", where *ⁿ* indicates a [nasalized vowel](/wiki/Nasalized_vowel). - The vowel 'io' is replaced by 'iau' (notation: a̤u), e.g. 笑 *ciao* "laugh". This also holds for nasalized vowels, e.g. 張 *da̤uⁿ* corresponding to Zhangzhou *tioⁿ*. - Nasals 'm' sometimes occur in place of voiced stops 'b', e.g. 夢 *mang* vs. Quanzhou *bang*. - Initial consonant 'ng' replaces 'g' e.g. 五 'ngo' vs. Quanzhou 'go'. - There is a loss of distinction between voiced and unvoiced stops, e.g. the sounds /b/ and /p/ both correspond to the same phoneme and occur in [free variation](/wiki/Free_variation). ### Borrowings from Eastern Min - Wife 老媽 (Lau Ma) ## Phonology This section **does not cite any sources**. Please help improve this section by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *(December 2024)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* Pu-Xian has 15 [consonants](/wiki/Consonants), including the [zero onset](/wiki/Zero_onset), the same as most other Min varieties. Pu-Xian is distinctive for having a [lateral fricative](/wiki/Lateral_fricative) [ɬ] instead of the [s] in other Min varieties, similar to [Taishanese](/wiki/Taishanese). Pu-Xian has 53 [finals](/wiki/Syllable#Structure) and 6 phonemic [tones](/wiki/Tone_(linguistics)). ### Initials Pu–Xian Min Initial Chart It has 23 letters: a a̤ b c ch d e e̤ g h i k l m n ng o o̤ p s t u ṳ.
